SPEECH.PARA: As an expression of my desire to ameliorate their plight and their fears in regard to nursing home charges, I implore the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) to again rethink the government's decision in this regard. The Director of Community Services at the GK Tucker Settlement, Ms Lesley Dredge, believes `a rise in entry contributions to the settlement will impact on low income people and only people with means will be able to buy their way back into the settlement'. She said, `It's really moving back to a system that supports people who have their own means.'

The GK Tucker Settlement, one of the first retirement villages in Australia, provides independent housing in a community atmosphere for financially disadvantaged elderly people. There is a hostel on the premises, which provides some 50 beds for frail people and has always been subsidised by the federal government. Currently, 86 per cent of the residents are deemed low income, but Ms Dredge has said, `We'll move to 100 per cent financially disadvantaged as soon as we are able.' Ms Dredge said that the settlement was one of the last of its kind in Australia and she is concerned that the low income elderly people will not have access to those levels.

Mr Ben Bennett, who has been a resident of the settlement for eight years, said that there is security there and residents are kept active, safe and secure in the environment that the settlement nurtures and provides. Mr Bennett said that he feels useful and it is like a family environment at the settlement. Mr Bennett has recently published a book about the settlement, providing an historical record of the years between 1935 and 1995.

In the limited time available, there is a second matter that I wish to draw to the attention of the Minister for Family Services. It concerns a constituent who recently approached me on Saturday morning at one of my mobile offices at a local shopping centre. She drew my attention to her plight. She and her husband are caring for her 79-year-old disabled mother at home. Her mother is rated as a nursing home No. 5 classification, which is the most serious in terms of needing care and continuous attention.

The aged lady in question was recently released from hospital. Her daughter and son-in-law were faced with the option of either placing her in a government subsidised nursing home or caring for her at their own home. For a range of reasons, including that the lady in question retains all her faculties, it was decided that she be cared for at home. Clearly the federal government benefits from this decision, as it is not forced to subsidise yet another nursing home occupant in a nursing home environment. Despite the fact that the carers receive the domiciliary nursing care benefit of $57.10 per fortnight—which helps to offset the cost of linkage care payments—a significant range of costs continues to be incurred by the carers. They are normally ineligible for anything other than assistance of that kind; that is, the domiciliary nursing care benefit of $57.10 per fortnight.

I request that, in light of the fact that such carers are saving the federal government money, the minister investigates the possibility of introducing an allowance for carers in this difficult situation. I have written to the minister to that effect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Entsch, Warren, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise tonight to bring to the attention of the House the wonderful contribution to my community of Cairns by the St Vincent's community services and, in particular, Ozanam House. Ozanam House was established over 40 years ago and caters for the needs of the poor and destitute in the Cairns community through the provision of services which include a meals service, temporary drop-in centre, 10 beds for short-term accommodation for single men, four units for crisis accommodation for families, outreach support and emergency relief.

SPEECH.PARA: At this point I would like to pay special tribute to the Manager of Ozanam House, Ann de Loryn, and a cook, Louise Maull. Both have given over 10 years of service to this most worthy organisation. Given the challenges and dramas and human misery they are forced to confront on a daily basis, I commend them. Their strength of character and goodwill have given much to the Cairns community.

I will give the House an indication of the magnitude of the services provided by Ozanam House. In the 1995-96 year, there were 50,122 meals served, 25,000 clients accessed their drop-in centre and shower and bathroom facilities, 5,100 obtained emergency relief assistance, 51 men were accommodated for an average stay of 12 weeks—of which 18 were referred from prisons or psychiatric units—and 59 individuals accessed the emergency accommodation with an average stay of 10 weeks. Many of these were from domestic violence situations.

This massive workload has been increasing annually at an alarming rate without anywhere near a reasonable proportional increase in resources. Until the beginning of this year, St Vincent's community services was funded to employ 4.5 persons, and they had to rely heavily on 27 volunteers—none of whom are professionally qualified to deal with this crisis situation, to carry out this magnificent work.

Since the beginning of this year, the demands on the centre have continued to grow. In the past three months, 12,808 meals have been provided, 4,290 have accessed the drop-in centre and shower facilities, 28 men and five families have accessed crisis accommodation and 1,056 people have been assisted with emergency relief.

Many of the clientele have major alcohol and drug abuse problems, while many others suffer from serious mental conditions—victims of previous governments' policies to deinstitutionalise mental health patients without providing adequate safety nets within the broader community. It is a sad indictment of our present society.

It is little wonder, given these facts, that the number of serious incidents requiring police and ambulance attention is continuing to escalate. In the past three months, the lives of volunteers and staff have been threatened on numerous occasions. They have had two drug and alcohol related epileptic seizures, six serious incidents of medical complications through drug and alcohol abuse, one attempted suicide and, sadly, recently one successful suicide. As a result, the volunteer levels have now been reduced to 13. Many of them are, in fact, clients of Ozanam House and their degree of assistance is not dependable. Sadly, St Vincent's community services is now faced with having to drastically reduce provision of services in an effort to survive.

I was pleased today to hear that the Queensland government has offered some relief in the form of a grant of $17,000 to St Vincent's for their weekend meals to continue, but this is not enough. We as a government have an obligation to look after those less fortunate in our community. What is needed urgently at Ozanam House is additional resources, in particular for qualified people, as this is far too great an imposition on charity workers. I therefore plead with my government to acknowledge the desperate situation currently facing Ozanam House and request that additional resources be made available immediately to ensure the long-term future of this worthy establishment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ronaldson, Michael, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr RONALDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of the Marine Personnel Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 is to make a number of small but important amendments to the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1992, the SRC Act, and to the Occupational Health and Safety (Maritime Industry) Act 1993, the OH&S (MI) Act.

The amendments to the two acts flow from recommendations by the tripartite Seafarers Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Authority—the seafarers authority—aimed at improving the administration of the workers compensation and occupational health and safety schemes, mainly by addressing a number of inconsistencies and anomalies in the current legislation. In developing its recommendations, the Seacare Authority consulted extensively with Australian ship operators, the insurers underwriting seafarers compensation liabilities and the maritime unions.

Schedule 1 of the bill amends the SRC Act. While there is a large number of amendments, the fundamentals of the seafarers compensation scheme will remain unchanged. There is, for example, no change proposed to entitlements or levels of benefits available to injured seafarers.

While acknowledging the hazardous work environment of many seafarers, the government is none the less seriously concerned at the Seacare Authority's 1995-96 annual report statistics which show a worsening claim rate and continuing high levels of longer term injuries, particularly among Maritime Union of Australia members.

One of the undertakings of the MEET under the 1994 maritime industry restructuring agreement was to cooperate with employers in stamping out compensation rorts. No such cooperation has been forthcoming. Furthermore, after more than 18 months of negotiations, the MEET has yet to implement a memorandum of agreement developed with employers on an effective shipboard rehabilitation policy to assist the reintegration of injured workers back into the work force. This results in a very significant cost burden to Australian ship operators, as reflected in their insurance premiums for workers compensation. It is a matter which the government will keep in mind while pursuing wider reforms in the shipping industry.

There are three amendments to the SRC Act to which your attention is drawn. The first of these is the proposed new section 20A at item 14 of schedule 1. That section will allow the Seacare Authority to exempt employment of specified employees on a particular ship from the application of the SRC Act. This will mainly have application where a ship which normally operates within the confines of a single state or territory is required to make a one-off interstate or overseas delivery voyage. Currently, such a ship would be covered by the SRC Act for that voyage and thus be required to have appropriate insurance cover, notwithstanding its crew would already be covered by the relevant state or territory compensation scheme, and the employer would be paying premiums under that scheme.

The Seacare Authority has received numerous complaints that this short‐term cover is difficult, and often impossible, to obtain and is prohibitively costly. The insurance companies also acknowledge this type of cover is, in many instances, not a normally acceptable commercial risk. The Seacare Authority will determine the appropriate conditions to apply before an exemption is granted, such as pre-existing coverage by a state scheme, and will prepare guidelines to advise ship operators of these conditions.

The second matter to which I draw the attention of the Main Committee is at item 75 of schedule 1. Section 93 is amended to provide that insurance policies under the SRC Act are not subject to state or territory stamp duty. This is to bring the seafarers compensation scheme into line with state and territory compensation schemes. No state or territory imposes stamp duty on workers compensation policies taken out under their own legislation.

Thirdly, I draw your attention to item 96 of schedule 1 which inserts a new section 139A into the SRC Act. That new section will exclude the operation of state and territory workers compensation laws where the SRC Act applies. The effect of the new section will be to prevent forum shopping; that is, where an injured seafarer shops around the various compensation schemes to find the scheme which pays the best benefits. Forum shopping has occurred mainly in respect of hearing loss because some states will pay compensation for a lower level of hearing loss than that set out under the SRC Act.

In addition, by virtue of the new section 139A, a state or territory will not be able to require a shipowner to pay state workers compensation premiums where the SRC Act applies. Currently, there is nothing to prevent this. The Seacare Authority is aware of instances of a ship operator being required to pay premiums for workers compensation insurance under both the SRC Act and a state workers compensation scheme. I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tanner, Lindsay, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Ronaldson) has outlined, the Marine Personnel Legislation Amendment Bill amends the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act and also the Occupational Health and Safety (Maritime Industry) Act. It is important to note, as the parliamentary secretary has pointed out, that the bill has been developed through the tripartite processes of the Seacare Authority and does have the strong support of not only the government, of course, but also the unions in the industry, employer organisations and other relevant parties, such as insurers. If for no other reason than that, the opposition also supports the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: There are three main provisions of the legislation and I would like to comment very briefly on each of them. The capacity for specific employees to be exempted from the operation of the legislation is of particular importance because individual vessels can move jurisdiction. Because the seamen's compensation legislation applies to interstate and international maritime industry activities, one of the situations that has caused difficulties in the past is vessels that have on the odd occasion undertaken a journey that is non‐intrastate, thereby bringing themselves within the Seafarers Rehabilitation Compensation Act jurisdiction. So the value of this particular revision is to provide a straightforward capacity to exempt seamen's compensation requirements in that situation. I understand it has proved something of a problem for people to get short‐term insurance cover for that brief period when they come within the seafarers compensation act.

The second provision, which I also wholeheartedly support, if for no other reason than it slightly reduces the cost burden on Australian shippers, is the removal of any liability for stamp duty with respect to insurance policies under the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act. This puts the legislation on the same footing as the various state compensation regimes.

The final of the three major changes which the parliamentary secretary referred to is the provision to ensure that forum shopping is no longer possible and that the potential circumstance where individual employers feel liable to pay two separate sets of insurance for the one set of workers in the one industrial situation is removed. Again, I wholeheartedly applaud that provision.

This is one of those areas where I have had personal experience. As a lawyer, I represented for a couple of years back in the early to mid‐1980s the then Seaman's Union in seamen's compensation matters. That was in the days of the Seaman's Compensation Act. At that point the act had not changed a great deal since it was originally enacted, which I think was in 1911—I suspect some of the officials present tonight could reflect on that.

Fortunately, in about 1992 the former government reformed that legislation and essentially brought it up to par, to a comparative level, with the various state workers compensation schemes and made it a reasonably comprehensive piece of legislation. A lot of the difficulties that had previously existed in seamen's compensation arrangements were removed. I should applaud the current government for the apparent fact that it has no obvious intention to fiddle too much with the arrangements that have been put in place and that the scheme remains substantially intact.

I commend the legislation to the House and make the point that it continues the process of removing the anomalies and difficulties, of which there were many in the original seamen's compensation legislation. It deals with issues such as jurisdiction. Having had to deal with injured seamen in a range of particular circumstances when I was a solicitor, I know, for example, how confusing it sometimes was to work out precisely which jurisdiction their particular claim was in.

The former act had a lot of problems with respect to enforcement processes. It is almost assumed in the legislation that the respondent would simply pay up and therefore if there was any denial of liability you could get into all sorts of difficulties pursuing the claim. It would ultimately have to go through the county court. When I ran such a case at one stage the county court found it very hard to handle. In Victoria, I think it had been decades since they had had one go to the county court and they did not quite know what to do about it. A lot of these things will be effectively fixed up with this legislation. This legislation is another important step in essentially bringing the legislation into a position where it dovetails neatly with the other compensation schemes that operate across Australia.

I would like to make some brief comments about the broader question raised in the second reading speech relating to the Maritime Union of Australia. It is true that, as part of an agreement with the former government, the Maritime Union committed itself to a serious attempt to eliminate rorting by seafarers of the seamen's compensation legislation. I noticed in the parliamentary secretary's second reading speech and also in the second reading speech in the Senate when the legislation was introduced there that the MUA was attacked for having done nothing to eliminate those rorts or to fulfil its promise.

I think that is probably a slightly jaundiced and unfair position to adopt. It is true that negotiations between the MUA and employers have taken some time and have not born fruit to a great extent as yet. It always takes two to tango in these situations. To be fair to both parties, it is important to remember that it is very easy to say about one individual, `That is a rort. In those particular individual circumstances this person should not be getting compensation. They have been off too long or whatever.' It is hard to draw a line which has some degree of integrity to ensure that that person does not get compensation while, at the same time, ensure that we are not also knocking off a number of people who should get compensation. We need to be mindful of the inherent difficulties that exist. I am still hopeful that, to the extent that there are problems there, they will be addressed by cooperation.

The other thing that is important to recognise—and I do not think this has been sufficiently acknowledged this evening although it was mentioned in passing—is that life at sea is inherently hard and very dangerous. I have represented injured workers in the building and construction industry. I have also represented workers in the manufacturing and metal industries and various other places. The nature of the injuries, the nature of the risks and the nature of the difficulties faced by seafarers in their employment, in spite of the major improvements in terms of safety and new technology that have occurred, are still very much up there with the worst that are faced in those other very dangerous industries I have mentioned.

The ship that we see when we are down at the port of Melbourne having a look around and we comment on by saying, `Isn't it wonderful. Isn't it nice,' is very different when it is out in heavy seas and there is water sloshing all over the decks and there is very heavy equipment around. You have a lot of risks and a lot of difficulties. The compensation issues are certainly very serious for working seafarers because serious injuries do happen and there are very substantial risks. Being at sea is an inherently dangerous activity. I think it is important that we keep that in mind.
I will turn now to the attitude that the government has with respect to the Maritime Union and the waterfront and shipping industries more generally.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pathological hatred.

—A pathological hatred is probably not an unjust description from the member for Throsby. The thing that worries and saddens me about this attitude is that it actually diminishes the government's potential to make some worthwhile achievements in these areas. It is gradually locking itself out of other possibilities of more sophisticated options where it can actually achieve some changes.

SPEECH.PARA: The reference to the MUA, and its alleged non‐activity or inactivity with respect to the compensation situation, disturbs me. It is worth noting that BHP and the Maritime Union reached an historic agreement that modified the trans‐Tasman agreement, of which the current government and current Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp) have been so critical. Our former government was also critical of it. When that agreement occurred, the minister was very quick to leap up and say, `Look what we've done; isn't it fantastic. We have only been in office a few months and already we've reformed the trans‐Tasman.'

Of course, the reality is that the minister had virtually nothing to do with it. It was really the work of BHP and the MUA that produced that agreement. The minister was there to run on the ground and grab the premiership cup five minutes before the final siren. I think this is something that the government should learn a lesson from—that is, encourage the parties in these difficult circumstances to reach agreement. Trying to claim the credit for agreements that are reached is not a good way to go about it.

Finally, and this applies right across the transport portfolio, the government has a very narrow perspective with respect to transport issues. This government sees transport as a cost. Transport is a cost on other industries and that is it. Coming from a person, in the case of this minister, who obviously has a close affinity with the interests of a constituency that consists of miners and farmers, that is an understandable attitude but, in my view, it is an inadequate attitude.

What it fails to acknowledge is that substantial parts of the transport sector are in fact major exporters. Qantas exports an enormous amount and we earn enormous export income from Qantas. It is our third biggest single exporter. That is just one example. Without an Australian flag shipping industry, we would have a substantial deterioration in our balance of payments.

We have a situation where these sorts of industries provide jobs—skilled jobs, well‐paid jobs—for many thousands of Australians. I think it is important, when discussing issues of efficiency, costs to other industries and the like—which are important; I do not deny that for a minute—that we do not lose sight of the fact that these industries also play other roles in our economy. I would urge the government, in developing its policies for the maritime industry, to keep all of those things in mind and not just focus on the issue of cost.

I hope that the government intends to maintain the basic structure of the seafarers' compensation and rehabilitation legislation that was put in place a few years ago because it modernised a very antiquated and outdated framework. The legislation we have before us tonight is, I think, another stage in finetuning and fixing up some of the problems that were not properly addressed at that time. I commend the legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Well may the hymn writer have written, `Oh hear us when we cry to thee, for those in peril on the sea.' As the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) said, it is a perilous occupation and it is fundamental that seafarers are protected by a decent and just compensation system.

SPEECH.PARA: In the early hours of the morning—about 3.15 a.m. to be precise—of 25 September, 1973 the motor vessel Erawan was proceeding quietly to its berth in Vancouver BC. A Japanese container vessel, the Sun Diamond, was leaving that same port. Both vessels were under the command of Canadian pilots at the time. They came into collision, with the Sun Diamond almost cutting the Erawan in two. There was a young Australian third engineer on the Erawan at the time of the collision. He felt the bump. The CO2 gas started discharging into the engine room. Of course, it floods the engine room and, unless you get out in a hurry, you do not survive.

The engine room was ordered to be evacuated but, in the meantime, it appeared that the second engineer and the chief engineer had gone down below to check if the engine room had been holed. The chief got out of the engine room and raised the alarm. The third engineer and the second mate went below and rescued the by then unconscious second engineer. Luckily, the second engineer escaped serious injury, as did the rest of the crew. But I can tell you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that the scars of that terrifying night still remain because I was, in fact, the third engineer on board that ship.

BREAK.PARA: In response to an earlier interjection by the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis): I do not think it is right to say that there is on this side a pathological hatred of the union movement. I was a member of the Australian Institute of Marine and Power Engineers—by choice, I might add; I did not have to be—and I was thankful to be so, particularly at the time of the events on that particular night and with the assistance I got after that.

I turn to the Marine Personnel Legislation Amendment Bill. This bill amends the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act and the Occupational Health and Safety (Maritime Industry) Act so as to streamline the application of those acts to seafarers injured in the course of their employment. It makes a number of small amendments which flow from recommendations by the tripartite Seafarers Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Authority. The amendments will improve the administration of workers compensation and occupational health and safety schemes. While there are a large number of amendments, the fundamentals of the act remain unchanged. There is certainly no change to the entitlements or benefits available to injured seafarers.

The government has been concerned by the increasing claim rate detailed in the 1995‐96 report of the seafarers authority. Higher levels of longer term injuries, particularly with members of the Maritime Union of Australia, were catalogued in that report. There was an undertaking by the MUA to cooperate with employers to stamp out what has been identified—I think without demur—as quite clear compensation irregularities and, some would say, rorts. But to date there has been little tangible cooperation.

The annual report of the Seafarers Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Authority states that there has been a reduction in the number of ships in the Australian fleet in the past year—that is, 1995‐96—and, consequently, the average number of seafarers covered by the principal act has fallen. The figures show that the average number of seafarers covered fell from 4,830 in 1994‐95 to 4,570 during 1995‐96. Of the 4,570 seafarers covered, approximately 3,900 were serving on ships that were covered by an industrial agreement or award. The total number of claims for 1995‐96 was 658, which was an overall increase on the 1994‐95 total of 574 claims. It should be noted that that is notwithstanding the lesser number of vessels in the Australian fleet.

Those sorts of figures clearly demonstrate that there was a need to bring in the amendments. I am pleased to see that the opposition has supported these measures. It is a relatively non‐contentious series of amendments, although the honourable member who recently resumed his seat made the comment that perhaps the government has not been as kind in its overall assessment as it ought to have been. I think the comments by the honourable member were really a bit of a sop to the MUA because, in effect, those figures are very hard to rebut.

While it is absolutely essential to ensure the safety that I mentioned before, it is also essential to deliver a system that will assist the overall financial running of these vessels so that we avoid the situation that was mentioned in the speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Ronaldson). He was referring to the situation where the particular act applies within the confines of a single state or territory but, if the vessel is required to make a one‐off trip overseas or a delivery voyage, extreme difficulties and costs are incurred by the shipowners in ensuring—because it is an absolute must under the present structure—that the crew members on that vessel are covered. That has caused undue premiums, inordinate costs to the shipowners and, ultimately, a less efficient system.

I agree with the honourable member for Melbourne (Mr Tanner) that it is important for the Australian shipping industry to continue. It is a very important industry for this country, but it must always be remembered that that can only happen with a cooperative approach by the MUA and all relevant unions, the shipowners and a government that is paying due regard to the need for reform in the maritime area.

These measures assist in that reform but, as is quite clear, the maritime industry in this country needs greater reform. It is important that the people working in that industry ensure that they deliver to the Australian people their side of the bargain. I am sure the government is mindful that its responsibility in this area is to make sure that their safety is ensured and that they are protected in ways that will encourage people who lead, as I said, a very dangerous, lonely, and at times quite frustrating existence. I support the measures in this bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis, Colin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is always a pleasure to follow the honourable member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) in debate, but let me say at the outset that, whatever his personal views may be, I do not resile one iota from my statement that many people—especially the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Sharp)—on that side have a pathological hatred of the Maritime Union of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: For the last 12 or 13 years I have participated in debates to do with shipping, and I have sat through many speeches by the now minister when he was a shadow minister. I have served on committees with him, I have heard his speeches and I have watched his actions concerning the Maritime Union of Australia.

Having said that and put the record straight, I am pleased to speak on this important legislation—the Marine Personnel Legislation Amendment Bill 1996. As was indicated in the second reading speech, the purpose of this bill is to make a number of small but important amendments to the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1992 and to the Occupational Health and Safety (Maritime Industry) Act 1993.

Like everyone else, the opposition supports this bill. However, although the opposition has indicated support for this bill, there are many issues with regard to marine personnel on which the opposition does not agree with the government. It is interesting that the bill under debate deals with occupational health and safety.

Occupational health and safety around the Australian coastline is going to become an issue of major importance over the coming years as this government moves, with its ill‐thought‐out plans, to open a second registry and open the Australian coastline to the rust buckets of the world by abolishing cabotage. No more ill‐considered move could be imagined.

The importance of retaining cabotage cannot be overemphasised. It is not just a question of Australia's balance of payments. It is a question of Australia's working conditions, Australia's image and Australia's position among the maritime nations of the world. How can we speak with any authority on shipping councils if we abolish cabotage and do some of the other things this government is proposing?

But, even more importantly, it is a major environmental issue. Over the last couple of weeks newspapers have been full of an environmental catastrophe in Japan. In recent years there have been environmental catastrophes off the coasts of Britain, the United States, South America, South Africa and Japan. Japan this week; Australia next. The one thing that these environmental disasters have in common is that they are, in the main, caused by flagships from ports of convenience. They, in the main, have ill‐equipped and ill‐trained crews.

BREAK.PARA: This government is making much of flogging off part of Telstra for an environmental package. It conned the environmental movement in the lead-up to the election by parading its new found environmental credentials. It got the support of a couple of so-called Independents, but I would have another name for those so-called Independents in the Senate.

If an oil spill occurs on the Great Barrier Reef it will take more than the part sale of Telstra to pay for the environmental damage. Yet this is a threat that this government is giving us through the opening of the Australian coastline to the rust buckets of the world. It is an environmental threat of monumental proportions.

For those of us who read the Daily Commercial News it is always interesting to read the monthly tally of ships that are detained because of defects. They range, in a low month, from, say, five, six or seven up to 25, 26 or 30 in a heavy month. The defects range from quite minor to quite substantial. This occurs now. Because of the work of this parliament in bringing down the Ships of shame report, many of the really disgraceful ships, such as the ones on the cattle run between Darwin and Indonesia—the real rust buckets; the real dangers—avoid Australia.

In the main, most of these really decrepit ships stay away from Australian ports. But this government, and especially this minister, is determined to put the Australian coastline at risk by doing away with cabotage. It is going to put our precious, environmentally sensitive coastline at risk. It is important that Australia prevents a further blow-out of our balance of payments through lost revenue by doing away with the Australian shipping industry. We have to prevent any further influx of flag of convenience vessels which do not adhere to recognised international standards on the Australian coastline.

I make no apology—absolutely no apology at all—for wanting to ensure ongoing employment for Australian seafarers and the jobs of people employed in the diverse industries which Australian shipping supports. Those opposite make much of how substantially well paid Australian seafarers are. But what they never say is that Australian seafarers are also the best trained and best qualified in the world.

I noticed in the speech of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Ronaldson) that the government attacked the Maritime Union, as is usual, saying that they had done nothing to redress issues of so-called rorts in compensation cases. They have worked on this. It is a difficult issue, but they have addressed it.

TALK.START.PARA: —What have they done?

—You are the parliamentary secretary; you tell me what they have not done. It would seem to me that Australia is best placed to meet our shipping tasks rather than becoming reliant on foreign shipping interests to service our needs.

BREAK.PARA: Over recent years substantial gains have been made in the maritime industry by adopting a tripartite approach to achieving productivity increases. Crew sizes have been reduced from 36 to 18. Demarcation was removed and multiskilling introduced. Yet the current federal government has appointed a group to look at winding back and removing cabotage and implementing a second register. It would come as no surprise that this group has no union participation.

In debating this bill dealing with marine personnel it is interesting to look at some recent examples of crew abuses carried out in Australian waters—precisely what would happen, only on a much wider scale, if our waters were open to the rust buckets of the world due to the abolition of cabotage.

The issue of occupational health and safety has assumed a high profile since the 1992 Ships of shame report and the subsequent 1995 report. The principal act provides a statutory scheme for compensating and rehabilitating seafarers who are injured in the course of their employment. In many respects it is similar to compensation regimes applicable to other Commonwealth employees. The principal act requires each employer to hold a suitable insurance policy and establishes the benefits payable to an incapacitated worker. Like the Comcare legislation, the emphasis of the principal act is on the rehabilitation of affected workers.

But what of injuries suffered by seafarers from other nations who are on other ships? There have been numerous examples. One case I particularly remember was of a Pakistani seafarer who lost a foot in Port Kembla. I inspected the ship and it had absolutely disgraceful conditions. This seafarer got absolutely nothing from the owners. He spent several months in Port Kembla hospital and he was looked after by the local unions and the Port Kembla Missions to Seamen.

There was also the disgraceful example concerning the Glory Cape, which I have raised in this parliament before, when a seafarer was murdered. I make no apology for saying that—a seafarer was murdered.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's true. You don't have to apologise.

—No, I am not apologising. I am stating categorically that the seafarer was one of many who have been murdered off the Australian coast. In that case, it was a Japanese owned, but Panamanian flagged, vessel where the crew was held and bashed with an iron bar when they complained about conditions. There was an undertaking given that the ship would not leave port and when they complained about the ship leaving port they were held and bashed with an iron bar. Five of the crew were bashed. One of the crew—the radio operator—jumped seven metres into the waters off Dampier in Western Australia. He was an Indonesian seafarer and he died as a result of this thuggery. As any fair‐minded person would say, he was murdered. This is still being investigated.

BREAK.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker, as you would well know, this is all too common in territorial waters around the world and it is becoming all too common in waters around Australia. Crews are underpaid, underfed, abused, bashed and often, especially if it is known that they have contacted the union, they just disappear. What protection is there here? It is very interesting the number of crews who complain to the union in Sydney or Melbourne, and who are sailing to Brisbane and never arrive in Brisbane. The water off the New South Wales coast has many bodies in it of seafarers from the Third World. These people have been pushed overboard, bashed—

TALK.START.PARA: —Helped overboard.

—Yes, helped overboard. I know that, if not tonight then certainly within the next week or so, my colleague the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) will elaborate on the recent case in Newcastle concerning the vessel MV Hunter when one seafarer went overboard from the Panamanian registered vessel. Conditions on that ship were highlighted by the fact that this crew member chose to swim ashore to alert authorities to those conditions. Eleven Honduran and Romanian crew members alleged mistreatment by the ship's officers and non‐payment of wages. The point I am making by highlighting what happened to the Glory Cape and the MV Hunter is that this is only the tip of the iceberg. We hear about one or two cases that terrify people. I would say there are not dozens, but hundreds of cases which never surface. Yet this is what this government has planned for Australia.

BREAK.PARA: While foreign ships carry most of our trade in and out of Australia, cabotage has restricted our coastal trade to Australian ships and crews, all well trained and working to recognise international safety standards. To hear the government talk about cabotage you would think we were the only country in the world that had this practice. Thirty‐two countries, including the US, have similar legislation, but that means nothing to the government who are planning to do away with cabotage, open up our coast to the rust buckets of the world and reduce conditions. We should hang our heads in shame.

Seventy per cent of the world's fleet is made up of flag of convenience vessels. These vessels flag out of tax havens like Panama. They do this to avoid regulations, such as those we are introducing tonight, that ensure ship safety and conditions meet world standards. As has recently been pointed out by the Maritime Union of Australia, flagging out a ship is like being able to register your car in Bali so you can drive it on Australian roads without having to get its brakes fixed. Flag of convenience ships are twice as likely to sink as international flag operators.

Two flag of convenience livestock carriers, Uniceb and Guernsey Express, went down at sea in 1996 carrying Australian sheep and cattle exports, to say nothing of the seafarers from the Third World. It is time this livestock trade was investigated by a parliamentary committee to highlight the conditions, as the Ships of shame committee did. Flag of convenience owners are infamous for their contempt of safety regulations and of the environment. When the Liberian flag of convenience tanker Sea Empress ran aground off the Welsh coast in 1996, it spewed 65,000 tonnes of crude oil over 100 kilometres of coastline. Australia narrowly missed a similar tragedy the same year when a flag of convenience vessel, Peacock, ran aground on the Great Barrier Reef.

As I have said time and time again, it is just good luck, rather than good management or good planning, that we have not had an environmental disaster of catastrophic proportions on the Great Barrier Reef—our premier tourist attraction. More often than not, flag of convenience owners fail to pay insurance premiums. So, if a disaster strikes, the Australian taxpayers will be hit with the clean‐up bill. How many more Telstras will have to be sold to pay for that? Substandard shipping accounts for more than 50 per cent of the world's pollution.

Australia has one of the youngest, most efficient and safest shipping fleets in the world. Australian seafarers are highly trained professionals, committed to reforming the industry and protecting the Australian environment. Can anyone trust rogue shipowners, employing Third World crews on starvation wages, to do the same? Despite legislation such as we are debating this evening and for which there is general agreement, there is no agreement on the future of the industry in Australia. Disaster, I suggest, is inevitable if this Liberal‐National Party government continues their ill‐thought‐out plans to abolish cabotage and open our precious coastline to the polluting rust buckets of the world. Having said that, I support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) has just said, the opposition supports the Marine Personnel Legislation Amendment Bill 1996 which is before the committee this evening. With reference to some of the remarks made earlier by one of the previous speakers from the government side about what progress is being made, let me say that, on an issue like this, the role of government is to give leadership. In the reform and improvement of the performance of Australian industry, government's role is not to divide, to decimate or to denigrate Australian industry. Its function is to give leadership, to be the catalyst and bring it together, and to show Australian industry how to do it better.

SPEECH.PARA: But, as the shadow minister for transport said earlier this evening, this government has a pathological hatred of the Maritime Union of Australia. That is a luxury it cannot much longer enjoy. It is stupid. It is damaging to Australia; it is certainly damaging to our balance of payments and our earnings from invisibles. But it is a luxury that those who are projecting it cannot very much longer enjoy, because the public sees through it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The antithesis of leadership.
—Oh, come off it, Daryl!

—The public expects of governments that they will give leadership in improving. The former minister for shipping, who is here, knows this picture very well. He and I have shared information on it for many years and together we could probably give some instruction and good advice to the current office holder. Doing what they are doing is not the right way to go about it. If you want to improve an industry, set about to be the catalyst, set about to give some leadership, and you will be surprised at what you can achieve.

SPEECH.PARA: What is happening is really a throwback to the 1970s. It is nice, cheap, nasty rhetoric, back on the stump. It is back on the stump—blame the unions. You can always get someone to blame; it is much easier to do than setting about to solve a problem. Solving problems is hard; giving leadership is very hard for some people.

TALK.START.PARA: —They can't accept responsibility.

—It is an inability to accept responsibility, but it is back on the stump. The former minister for shipping did not indulge in that kind of behaviour and I pay him that credit—his successors did. It is in giving that leadership role that I see a lamentable deficiency in this government.

SPEECH.PARA: Turning to the legislation itself—I will not recount its content because it has been covered by several other speakers—I want to say something about the report of the Seacare Authority and about the authority itself which supervises the performance of insurance companies in workers compensation payments.

This is a representative authority. The chairman of it is the chairman of the board of the Commonwealth superannuation scheme. The deputy chair is George Paton, Professor of Law at Melbourne University. He conducted the 1987‐88 seamen's compensation review which formed the basis for the legislation that we are now discussing tonight. Paul McGrath, the chief executive officer of the Australian Maritime Safety Authority is a member, and that is appropriate because he has a contribution to make. Another member is Geoffrey Leigh Harding, manager of human resources, ASP Ship Management and a member of the Australian Maritime Industry Compensation Agency. He is another important person to be there from that sector of the industry because ship management, as distinct from ship ownership, is a very important facet of a shipping industry overall.

Trevor Taylor is another member. He is the manager of national operations of the Australian Mines and Minerals Association which speaks for the minerals industry. It is a major user of Australian shipping with the export of coal, iron ore, alumina and other minerals and a major user of the foreign ships that ply our shores. You do not see that association carrying on with some of the rhetoric that we hear coming from this government. You might ask yourself why. It is because they are in business. They cannot afford the damage, the disruption and the dissension that that kind of cheap talk brings. These are cheap thrills. We can always run it off with a couple of paragraphs, but it does not address the problem in the national interest.

Michael Fleming, the joint national secretary of the Australian Maritime Officers Union has been replaced by Martin Burn of the Australian Institute of Marine and Power Engineers. Again, it is a good selection for that part of the trade union movement. Padre Crumlin, deputy joint national secretary of the Maritime Union of Australia who represents the interests of seafarers has been reappointed.

So the authority has a good balanced board. There is a good approach to it and I am pleased the government is carrying on with that. Look down to the overview of the organisation and the authority and see the functions performed—I will not run through all of them here. For example, it is to promote high operational standards of claims management and effective rehabilitation procedures by employers—the same kinds of principles that we apply in respect of Comcare.

In Comcare we do not get up screaming, `Public servants are making too many claims and all hell shall fall upon them.' We say, `What is the problem? How can we improve the rehabilitation management plans? How do we get them back to work sooner?' That is one hell of a hard job for management. There has been considerable improvement made in that area over the past 10 years. The authority monitors the operation of the Seafarers Rehabilitation and Compensation Act and promotes high operational standards of claims management and effective rehabilitation procedures for employees which I have referred to.

It goes on with the other matters. The important one is to accredit occupational health and safety training courses for the purposes of section 47 of the Occupational Health and Safety (Maritime Industry) Act. They are all important functions which are part and parcel of the approach to a recognition that working at sea is a dangerous occupation. It is a hostile environment and it can be excessively hostile at times, as previous speakers have described. It very much depends upon the training and competency of crew, and the quality of equipment and the ship.

You can walk on board a ship in port, or you can walk by a ship in port and within a few minutes you can say, `That is a well‐maintained ship.' Or you can say, `That is a ship that is poorly maintained.' If it is poorly maintained, it is also likely that there are greasy substances on the deck; the deck has not been properly cleaned; there are cables lying about, or other impediments on the deck. These are all things that go to sloppy management of a ship and sloppy management of crew, and they lead to higher rates of incidents, injuries and claims.

Exactly the same thing happens on a plant ashore. It is no different. One factory is at sea and the other factory is at shore. If you have bad management at the factory ashore, you also have a high incidence of claims.

As you go through the report, you come across the issues about which there has been consultation with the states. I will come back to the figures in a moment. I refer to the Ships of shame: a sequel report of November 1995 by the former Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. The member for Throsby referred to part of that report in his comments about the Pakistani seafarer who broke his foot. My recollection of that incident was that he hurt his foot on a forklift. He had not been trained to drive a forklift. When they sought to see what injury he had been caused, the response from the ship's officer was, `Get him back on board. He's okay.' They tried to get him back on board. They refused to get him a doctor. Eventually, the unions ashore insisted that the man get medical aid. It was only after some considerable time when the man was injured that they discovered his foot was broken. The company then refused to meet the cost of the necessary treatment.

I turn to paragraphs 2.39, 2.40 and 2.41 on page 13 of Ships of shame: a sequel. The point we made in this report is that there are different jurisdictions. Take the case of the fellow driving the forklift. On the wharf, he would have been covered by state legislation. If he were up on the ship, he would have been covered by this legislation. But if he were international, he would have been covered by international legislation, if you can get delivery of the entitlements that are there. The odds are that with Panamanian ships and some of the other flags of convenience, or flags of shame, as I tend to call them now, there is very little likelihood that they will get the compensation or benefits they are entitled to.

We said that incidents on the ship may be treated differently from incidents that occur on the wharf. I have explained that. That information highlighted to us as a committee during our inquiry the wider problem of reporting injury and illnesses. What happens is that injuries on many foreign ships coming here are not reported. If they report the injuries, they will be responsible for any medical care that may be necessary.

You might say that in all these things Australian shipping has to be competitive with world markets. You can compete with lower wages and lower compensation entitlements by better technology, working smarter and all those things that Australians are good at. However, you cannot compete with no compensation and no wages. I defy any minister, government or company executive to handle that challenge. You can compete with lower standards, but you cannot compete with no payment at all. That is what happens in some cases.

Paragraph 2.40 refers to the fatal accidents occurring on foreign flagged ships that were not investigated by the proper authorities because the master did not report them. The next point deals with the differing requirements for occupational health and safety matters and those that fall within the ambit of the Navigation (Marine Casualty) Regulations. That was found in a review inquiry in 1995 at pages 453 to 457.
At paragraph 2.41 of the report, we state:
The committee believes that the issue of jurisdiction in OHS matters which arises in these and similar cases should be clarified. Two matters requiring attention are:
(i) unqualified ship's crew driving ship's equipment.
That was referred to earlier. It can also happen with Australian personnel ashore and on board ship. The second point is this:
(ii) the jurisdictional boundaries between the Commonwealth OHS Acts, the Navigation Act and its Marine Orders (particularly Part 32) and the various State OHS Acts which cover waterside workers.

Page 12 of the report of the Seafarers Safety, Rehabilitation and Compensation Authority states that there is action under way as a result of that recommendation. I am pleased that the former chairman of the committee has seen that that is happening. It is being taken seriously. I hope that it can be expedited.

In February 1996, there was a meeting between representatives of the authority, AMSA and WorkCover of New South Wales to discuss jurisdictional issues. It goes on to say that a discussion paper on the proposed memorandum of understanding was subsequently developed. It then states:

BREAK.PARA: This paper is expected to be circulated to the other State and Territory occupational health and safety authorities early in 1996-97.

I ask the parliamentary secretary, if he responds in this debate, or anyone else who responds to advise the committee of what progress has been made in respect of that document and what has been the response of the states.

The same page of the report refers to the ILO, or International Labour Organisation, code of practice on accident prevention on board ships at sea and in port. They are matters I have referred to. It states:

Consultations are continuing with AMSA and the maritime industry on appropriate modifications to the Code to reflect Australian standards, where these standards are superior to those set out in the Code.
This is an extremely important matter.

This leads me to what I mentioned earlier, which are the statistics in the back of the report. These statistics are referred to by the minister in his press statement of 30 October 1996, which has the headline `Seafarers Compensation Costs Continue to Climb'. He states:
Workers' compensation costs for Australian seafarers continue to increase and now are estimated to be more than three times those of general industry.

You do not compare costs on a ship in that environment with costs in general industry. You compare it with something like the construction industry or the mining industry. You compare those that are alike; that is, industries that have hostile environments where the actual claim rate and incident rate are much higher than the rates of general industry.
The minister does not state the numbers in the press release. He then goes on to state:
"The high compensation claim rate, particularly by MUA members, is seriously impacting on the costs of the scheme with estimates running as high as ten per cent of wages costs . . .
And so it goes on. He makes the point that additional crew must be engaged to cover absences on workers compensation. He then lapses into his other attacks on the MUA.

I must say that the Maritime Union of Australia, in all seriousness, is not the centre of the universe. There are things happening in the world other than the existence, operation and activities of the Maritime Union of Australia. It is true that if there is a higher claim rate or injury rate for occupational health and safety, it could lead to a high crew-berth ratio, whereby you need to make sure you have enough crew to make up for the people away. You could also say that it might add to costs.

I will turn to the figures in one table of the report in a moment. Before I do that, let me say that I was involved in the discussion a few weeks ago with representatives of the Australian Shipowners Association and Australian ship management personnel from the Maritime Union of Australia and other people associated with the industry. We talked about those comments of the minister, not specifically from his press statement but about this report.

What really surprised me—I bring it to the attention of the committee—is that we had three different views. What was fascinating about the discussion was that when we started to interpret those figures and ask, `How is this so?', we heard three different points of view. From the union's point of view, there was the ready recognition of a problem. I will mention the figures in a moment so the committee can hear some of the problems. But they thought that it was being addressed. They felt that, in association with ship management and owners, the solution to that problem was well under way.

The ship management company said, `We don't have that problem. Our rates haven't gone up.' There were several different points of view from ship owners. Some had and some had not. That said that it depends very much upon the quality of management of the individual firm involved, as it does with any other industry ashore. So you do not lambast all the people working in the industry, because some managers are better than others.

If you look at table 2, you will see that the claim rate for trainees, comparing 1993-94 with 1995-96, went from 6.3 per cent to 23.4 per cent. Obviously, there is a problem with trainees that needs to be addressed. Who is employing more trainees? There is something wrong there. They say that it is being addressed.

Look at the increase in the location of the injuries. Injuries for those working on ships jumped from 497 to 647 over the same period, from 1993-94 to 1995-96. Look at the body parts affected. The big increases were in back injuries, the number of which rose from 106 and 130, and upper limb injuries, which went from 123 to 173. Look at the mechanism of the injury. The big increase was in muscular stress by lifting, carrying or lowering objects. It went from 88 to 164, which is almost double. You do not have to be Sherlock Holmes to work out where the problem is and what the company needs to do. That is how the industry needs to address this problem. The government should not simply blame all of the industry.

If you turn to table 8 on page 19, you will see that strains, sprains of joints and adjacent muscles went from 274 to 348 and that hernias went from 15 to 24. That is a pretty important figure. There has been a 50 per cent increase in the frequency of hernia claims. I do not think you can fake a hernia, unless there is a new form of acting. That kind of injury is pretty explicit. All I say is that the legislation is important. We need to go through it and identify the problem and set about solving it rather than just lambast the people who work in the industry.

I conclude by turning to some headlines from the Malaysian International Shipping Corporation. This is dated 23 January 1997, comes from DCN and is entitled `Foreign Lines Chase Australian Officers'. What this company and the reporters are saying is that Australian maritime officers are highly skilled, well recognised and well paid. It mentions the companies concerned. The conclusion states:
"Today, Mobil is probably paying the best rates and conditions worldwide. That includes 25 days leave for every month served.

That is pretty close to six months on and six months off. It is 25 to 30 days. There are 28 days in February. It is almost a par. That argument does not have the substance that has been put on it from time to time.

Another article entitled `Seafarer Training the Top Priority' states that if there is a problem, we should address it by training and competence, as I said in my opening remarks. The revised Standard Training Certification Watchkeeping Convention is due to come into operation before long. There is worldwide pressure to ensure that competency standards are up and that people are trained.

I want to quote Captain P Chawla, the safety and quality manager for Anglo‐Eastern Ship Management of Hong Kong. He told delegates from the shipping industry of one of the most important reasons why seafarers have a poor attitude to their job and one of the main reasons for accidents. This is not about Australians; this is about those seafarers who the minister loves to extol and point to as a model. This is what some of the people in the business in a big way have to say. He said that one of the main reasons for accidents is the inadequate support provided to him by the shore side support organisations. He said that it is not a very popular statistic with managers but it is a well‐known fact that 60 per cent of all accidents can be traced back to management errors. I rest my case on that. I have tried to draw all it altogether. (Time expired)

TALKER.NAME: Mr RONALDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —We're a bit more resilient than the Tories.

—The member for Throsby says that in some areas they had a swing towards them. You got an absolute shellacking and you still will not accept that you got a hiding. SPEECH.PARA: I thank the shadow minister for his constructive input into the debate.
