PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 4 December 1996, on motion by Mr Williams:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will be supporting this bill. The general outline on page 1 of the explanatory memorandum sets out the principal objects of these amendments. I think it is worth while quoting from the explanatory memorandum because it summarises the bill fairly simply. It says:

SPEECH.PARA: The principal object of these amendments is to give effect to several recommendations of Checking the cash: a report on the effectiveness of the Financial Transaction Reports Act 1988 , a report by the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs of 1993.

Those recommendations that are being given legislative effect are: recommendation 12, access to FTR information by state and territory revenue authorities; recommendation 15, which is the definition of transaction; recommendation 16, which is inadmissibility of suspect transaction report information; recommendation 18, increase in the reporting threshold for imported and exported currency and definition of the point at which currency transferred is considered to have been exported; and recommendation 19, bullion sellers required to identify customers.

The other features of the bill are: the introduction of significant cash transaction reporting by solicitors, and I will come to that later on; consolidation of the powers of inspection of AUSTRAC to access and examine the records and record keeping systems of persons required to keep records under the act; updating of the penalty provisions of the act in accordance with current drafting practices and alignment of the quantum and expression of penalties with those in other Commonwealth statutes; updating other specific provisions that contain superseded terminology or are otherwise in need of modernising; and the making of minor technical amendments to correct minor drafting errors. It is for that reason—it is pretty non‐controversial—that the opposition will be supporting the bill before the House.

The Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) in his second reading speech pointed out that the principal act we are amending is part of the Commonwealth package of legislation that was developed following the Costigan Royal Commission into the Painters and Dockers Union to combat organised crime. The principal act basically erects barriers in Australia's financial sector to discourage use of this sector by criminals and allows the provision of financial intelligence to law enforcement and revenue agencies.

The act plays a major role as an intelligence tool, able to expose the illicit movement of money, particularly cash, and to facilitate the following of a money trail, both back to its source to identify the financiers and organisers of criminal enterprises, and outwards to locate the proceeds of crime, which may then be available for confiscation under the provisions of the Proceeds of Crime Act 1987, another component of the anti‐organised crime package. AUSTRAC is the agency constituted under the Financial Transaction Reports Act to receive, analyse and distribute to law enforcement and revenue agencies information received from the cash dealers covered by the legislation.

Two issues in particular are worthy of note, and they are the ones that I wish to highlight this evening. The first is that the Senate committee raised concerns about the appropriateness of privacy protections if financial transaction reports information was provided to state and territory authorities. The bill requires those authorities to comply with the privacy principles set out in section 14 of the Privacy Act 1988 in order to assess FTR information. That is item 52, subclause 27(1)(c) of the bill. Basically, it states that:

the Director may, in writing, authorise a revenue authority of a State or Territory to have access to FTR information for the purpose of performing its functions if the authority undertakes that it will comply with the Information Privacy Principles set out in section 14 of the Privacy Act 1988 in respect of FTR information obtained under the authorisation; . . .
The bill also makes it an offence for an officer of a revenue authority to improperly disclose the information. That is item 55, subclause 27(9).

Another feature of the bill is that it extends the application of suspect transaction reporting to solicitors. That is item 26, clause 15A. It should be pointed out that this measure was supported by the previous Minister for Justice, the Hon. Duncan Kerr MP, who foreshadowed that the Labor government would introduce similar changes. The Costigan royal commission, the National Crime Authority and the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs uncovered considerable evidence that solicitors trust accounts may be being used to launder the proceeds of crime.
With respect to item 26, which is on cash transaction reports by solicitors, on page 6 of the explanatory memorandum it says:

New s 15A requires a solicitor to report significant cash transactions which are entered into by or on behalf of the solicitor in the course of practising as a solicitor. A person who practises exclusively as a barrister is not required to report. A significant cash transaction is a transaction of $10,000 or more in currency (that is, cash).
The report must be prepared before the end of the reporting period, which is defined in ss 3(1).
There is also a new subsection 15A(2) which states:

the report must be in the approved form, contain the reportable details of the transaction and be signed by the solicitor or otherwise authenticated by the solicitor in the approved way. These reportable details are contained in new Schedule 3A to the Act, which is inserted by the Bill.

In his second reading speech, the Attorney‐General and Minister for Justice justified the inclusion of these provisions. I think it is worth while quoting from his second reading speech. On page 6 he says:
That is not an amendment which was recommended by the Senate Committee.

I have decided that the Financial Transaction Reports Act should be amended to require solicitors to report to AUSTRAC all transactions with their clients of $10,000 or more in cash—that is, in currency.
They would also be required to include in the report particulars of the client's identity, as known to them.

Over a decade ago, in 1984, the Costigan commission—the Royal Commission on the Activities of the Federated Ship Painters and Dockers Union—reported that some solicitors had let their trust accounts and perhaps their strongrooms be used as a means of parking and laundering illegally obtained funds. In its report, the commission noted that:

There is no doubt on a great deal of the evidence before me that certain solicitors have allowed their trust account, if not their strong rooms, to be employed as repositories for monies, the source of which, on any rational view, could only be illegal enterprises.
The commission's report goes on to say:
By depositing monies with such solicitors, some hope or expectation is held that law enforcement agencies will have difficulty in locating the funds and in seeking explanations for them.

More recently, in 1991, the National Crime Authority undertook a study into money laundering in Australia. It found that solicitors had often played a part in money laundering operations by assisting in the purchase of property in a way that disguised the source of the funds or the identity of the owner; for instance, the use of false names or `nominee companies' and through trusts.

The NCA found that solicitors also assisted money launderers by placing cash proceeds in trust accounts; for instance, before settlement of property purchases or for sending overseas—by wire transfer—or for returning to the criminal in the form of a loan. Another technique the NCA reported was used by solicitors was the arranging of false loans with other parties on behalf of criminals. The loans were repaid with the proceeds of criminal activities.

The Attorney-General went on in his second reading speech to say that evidence presented to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in 1993 indicated that solicitors in some areas of Australia—in particular, suburban practices in Sydney, Melbourne, Brisbane and the Gold Coast—are handling significant amounts of cash on behalf of clients. He went on to conclude:

The present exclusion of solicitors from the reporting provisions of the FTR Act could represent a loophole capable of being exploited by criminals seeking to evade those provisions for the purpose of evading tax or laundering the proceeds of crime.

The sad reality is that the Attorney-General and Minister for Justice is spot on. The tragedy is that some solicitors are corrupt. There are rotten eggs in the system, and this is a loophole that needs to be closed.

The great tragedy is that we are dealing with large amounts of money. There is no doubt—this should not be seen to be a slur on all solicitors; it is a recognition that there are good apples and bad apples in every single profession in this country—that some solicitors and some lawyers act hand in hand with the criminal element in this country. It is for that reason that we think that what the minister is doing is reasonable in all the circumstances. We agree with the objects of the act and the objects of the amendments.

We also need to get this into perspective because I think there are some instances where we on this side of the House will not support the pursuit of crime because there are civil liberties aspects, but we do not believe this is one of them. The amendments in this bill are uncontroversial and should have the support of all sides of the House. The opposition has no problem in supporting them.

Apart from that, the other measures in the bill are fairly straightforward. I know my colleague who follows me, the member for Maribyrnong (Mr Sercombe), has something to say because he has a different view in relation to some aspects of the legislation. But I do commend the legislation to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sercombe, Bob,MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I propose to keep my remarks pretty short on the Financial Transaction Reports Amendment Bill 1996. In 1995, AUSTRAC received a report from a consultant, John Walker, in which he made estimates of the extent of money laundering in and through Australia. Frankly, the extent of the problem is mind-boggling to most people. The estimates that Walker gave ranged from $1 billion to $4.5 billion, with $3.5 billion in criminal profit generated in and laundered through Australia every year being his best estimate. Internationally, the proceeds of money laundering are estimated at somewhere between $500 billion to $1,100 billion per annum, with some estimates upwards of $US4 trillion. The great bulk of laundered funds is derived from the proceeds of the drug trade, arms smuggling, terrorism, tax evasion and the like. So we are dealing with a problem of very considerable significance.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the issues that are before the parliament at the moment are likely to be revisited with increasing regularity, not only given the size of the issues that we are dealing with but also the extent to which we are experiencing a change in the world in which commerce occurs. The Attorney-General (Mr Williams) has before him at the present time a report prepared by a group called the electronic commerce task force for the Commonwealth Law Enforcement Board. This report makes it very clear that the world in which commercial transactions, including criminal commercial transactions, are occurring is changing rapidly and increasing in sophistication. The application of telecommunications, information technology and encryption technology to money laundering and other aspects of criminal behaviour is going to mean that the issues around financial transactions and the way in which Australia of necessity, in collaboration with other jurisdictions, addresses these problems is going to increasingly exercise this parliament.

I will just read a portion of the second reading speech of the Financial Transaction Reports Bill which was given in 1987 by the then Attorney-General, Mr Bowen, because, despite the changes I have referred to, it still underlines the continuing importance of these matters. Mr Bowen said:

This bill represents one of the most significant initiatives to counter the underground cash economy, tax evasion and money laundering. It is notorious that the underground cash economy provides great scope for tax evasion, both domestically and internationally. It is clear that traditional investigative techniques have been ineffective in identifying financiers of major crime, because of the ease with which such persons are able to distance themselves from the actual criminal conduct. However, experience both in Australia and overseas has shown that the financiers are more closely associated with the profits of crime. That experience also shows that cash is an important part of financing criminal activity.

Ten years later those observations are just as true now as they were then but in a more complex, more sophisticated environment, which leads me to the observations I made before about the fact that I think this particular area is one that we are going to have to revisit with increasing frequency.

I do not intend to go through many aspects of the bill in any detail because of time and my desire to wrap up quickly. My colleague the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) dealt with the most controversial aspect of the legislation, and that is that the bill picks up—against the recommendation of the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs—some proposals in relation to the accountability of solicitors under AUSTRAC and financial transactions legislation generally. I think that is a very serious step, given the importance of legal privilege and a whole range of other matters in the client‐legal adviser relationship, for this parliament to be taking. On balance, the parliament is coming down in support of taking those steps. But it seems to me that that is a matter that ought to be kept under rigorous and continual review, probably by an appropriate committee of the parliament, to ensure that the intentions are being met adequately.

Another aspect of the bill that does cause me a little concern is the possibility of a creep, as it were, of AUSTRAC coverage that may arise from the provisions of the bill to improve the access to AUSTRAC data from state organisations. The submission from the Victorian State Revenue Office to the Senate committee, which forms the basis of the proposals in this legislation to extend its coverage to state revenue offices, makes it clear that the states did derive considerable benefit from their participation in 1991 in investigations of evasion of tobacco licences. It is on the basis of the success of that operation that the states have put forward a proposition, which has been accepted, that their revenue authorities gain access to AUSTRAC data. That is also a matter that will require very careful and continuing monitoring, given that the decision has now been taken.

It seems to me that the pressures may well increase for further creeping of access to AUSTRAC data. I refer, for example, to the section of the Senate report which deals with the question of whether the Department of Social Security ought to be given access to the data. I will just read one sentence from the report:

BREAK.PARA: The Committee stresses that AUSTRAC was established to respond to major crime, not lesser breaches of the law such as more minor breaches of the Social Security Act.

It goes on and talks about the difficulties of illegal disclosure of social security information and the like. It is a very serious matter to provide the sort of data that AUSTRAC has, and any expansion of its coverage ought to be subject to very careful consideration. Frankly, it ought to be, as I said before, under continual review. It would be helpful to have some assurances from the Attorney‐General that in fact he is cognisant of that and intends to institute some sorts of processes whereby that review occurs.

The final thing I want to say very briefly is that there are a number of other recommendations in the Senate committee report that have not been picked up in this legislation, and it would be helpful to get an understanding from the Attorney‐General as to why.
Recommendation 5, for example, is along the following lines:
The Committee recommends that the present account opening requirements of the FTR Act should no longer be a mandatory minimal procedure.
In other words, the committee recommended somewhat simpler processes there, and it does not appear the government is picking that up.
Recommendation 7 says:
The Committee recommends that the FTR Act be amended so that the ATO no longer has a right of access but has access on the same basis as law enforcement agencies.
Once again, it is not picked up in the legislation, and it would be helpful to know why.
Recommendation 8 recommends that a civil liberties representative be appointed to the ministerial advisory committee on the act—a recommendation not picked up.
Recommendation 9 is:

The Committee recommends that the advice of a Privacy Commissioner be sought by the Director of AUSTRAC whether to appoint a civil liberties representative . . . or establish a separate advisory committee . . .
This was not picked up. It would be useful to know why.
Recommendation 17 is:
The Committee considers there should not be strict liability under section 31. It should be required that the prosecution establish—

I am sorry, I think this one may have been picked up, so I will move on. The point remains that there are a number of aspects of the Senate committee report that have not been picked up in this legislation with no explanation, and it would be helpful to have that explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Howard government, in its policy launch statement on 18 February last year, committed itself to undertaking reforms that would make Australia better off. Whether Australia is actually benefiting so far from the coalition's policies is, of course, the subject of ongoing and passionate debate. Understandably, that debate has tended to focus on areas involving micro‐economic reform and social policy.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill, the Financial Transaction Reports Amendment Bill 1996, is an example that should see Australians better off. The bill is intended to close loopholes that have been utilised by criminals to undermine the integrity of the financial sector. It is essential to ensure that there is a balance between reducing the risk of Australia's financial sector being abused by criminals in a way which circumvents the government's intentions without impinging on the confidential nature of the solicitor‐client relationship and wider third party privacy.

BREAK.PARA: Recent history has shown that current financial transaction reporting practices fall short of adequately protecting the financial sector from criminal abuse. The Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, to which others have referred, made some 23 recommendations in its 1993 report into the Financial Transactions Report Act 1988, the principal act. These recommendations addressed a wide range of issues as to how reporting financial transactions could be improved in our country. The recommendations included the setting of new threshold amounts, the methods of reporting, the powers of AUSTRAC and who should have access to information about sizeable transactions.

The coalition government has chosen to proceed with this bill without making any significant changes to those proposed by the previous Labor government. It has chosen to address only five of the 23 recommendations made by the Senate standing committee in this proposed legislation. In many cases this is because the recommendations of the Senate committee did not require legislation to be put into effect.

One of the more important recommendations made by the committee related to the ongoing access of state and territory revenue authorities to financial transaction reporting, FTR, data. As the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) indicated in his second reading speech, Operation Quit which involved Commonwealth, state and territory authorities revealed a significant licence fee fraud in the tobacco industry in the early 1990s. The uncovering of that and the success of the operation highlighted the benefits flowing from state and territory authorities having continued access to FTR information.

However, the Senate standing committee recommended that these revenue authorities should have ongoing access to this information only after they had signed a memorandum of understanding with the director of AUSTRAC. That was a sound and reasonable recommendation. The proposed memorandum of understanding would require the state and territory revenue bodies to abide by privacy safeguards set out in the Commonwealth's Privacy Act 1988. It would offer protection to those parties involved in any financial transaction exceeding $10,000. Such a safeguard seems both logical and necessary and it is pleasing to see it has been addressed in this bill.

There is concern amongst some legal practitioners about the lack of definition of some of the features of the bill. The Attorney‐General in his second reading speech referred to the intended meaning of the term `transaction' in the proposed bill. The Attorney‐General noted that the legislation was being amended to include recommendation 15 of the standing committee's report. He also made it clear that under the changes the meaning of a transaction would include a proposal or negotiation for a transaction so that negotiations terminated before their completion would be taken into account. The Attorney‐General went on to say, `Transaction is not defined in the principal act and simply has its normal meaning.'

The Law Council of Australia has not signalled to me its opposition to the inclusion of negotiations that are terminated in the definition of a transaction but it is very concerned about the lack of definition of the original word `transaction' in the context of the principal act. In a letter sent to the Attorney‐General in February of this year the Law Council observed, `The term "transaction" used in the act may mean the specific receipt by a solicitor from a client of cash in excess of $10,000 and the deposit by the solicitor of that cash into the solicitor's trust account. On the other hand, the term "transaction" potentially may mean that the whole matter of the client, in respect of which cash may be received by the solicitor'.

This lack of explanation is causing considerable angst amongst some in the legal profession. However, today I received advice from the Attorney-General's Department that, while the term `transaction' is not defined in the principal act, the term `cash transaction' is. Section 3 of the original act makes a very specific reference to that term and should not be open to interpretation.

The Law Council has also suggested that this loose definition complicates other parts of this legislation. It notes that subsection 15A(1) compels a solicitor to report on a transaction before the end of the reporting period. Given that the term `transaction' is not, in the eyes of some in the profession, satisfactorily defined, the Law Council argues that there is ambiguity about what `the day on which the transaction takes place' actually means. However, as a non-lawyer I am reasonably satisfied with advice provided by the Attorney-General's Department about references to the term `transaction' and believe that there is little room for another translation in this instance.

The Law Council also questions why the reporting period for domestic currency is the end of 15 days after the date on which the transaction takes place, when a solicitor has only one day to report on a significant transaction that involves foreign tender. I understand that the Attorney‐General's Department has had some difficulty in ascertaining why such a significant variation exists. I am told that, while the department is reluctant to alter the current amendments, which we are debating, when it is so close to being enacted, it is happy to look at this imbalance at a later date and, if possible, correct it.

The government has chosen to clarify the point at which currency transferred is deemed to have been exported. In doing so, it has actioned one of the recommendations of the Senate standing committee. Item 25 of the explanatory memorandum makes it very clear that currency will be considered to have been exported when `a person has surrendered custody or control of an article with the intention of transferring the article.' That is a sensible clarification.

This bill also seeks to enact changes to the actual details on transactions exceeding $10,000, which a solicitor must include in a report. Item 75 delineates the information that will be expected to be accounted by solicitors. The five items include: details about the nature of the transaction; details of the solicitor, corporation or partnership; details of each other person who is a party to the transaction; details of where the transaction was conducted on behalf of a principal; and details of where a cheque or banker's draft is involved with the transaction.

Items 1 and 3 are of special interest to the Law Council. It asserts that there is ambiguity in the word `nature' when it is used in the term `nature of the transaction'. Indeed, there is no such definition of it in the explanatory memorandum accompanying the bill. The Law Council suggests that if taken literally it could be that solicitors have to provide details of the entire transaction in which their client is involved. That would threaten the confidential nature of the solicitor‐client affiliation and, therefore, in my view, warrants a review.

The Law Council is equally concerned about a solicitor having to provide details about other persons involved in a transaction over $10,000, as outlaid in item 3 of schedule 3A. In its letter to the Attorney‐General, the Law Council said:
If a broad view of the term `transaction' is taken . . . the solicitor will be obliged to provide the details of each person who is a party to the transaction.
The letter went on to say:
This involves the solicitor being required to provide details of the name, business or residential address, occupation and date of birth of parties other than the party who has deposited the cash.

This legislation will compel solicitors to provide information that goes beyond the reporting of a client, and the receipt of a transaction deposit that exceeds the threshold of $10,000, as far as I can ascertain.

The Law Council maintains that that represents a gross invasion of privacy of any third party involved in a significant transaction. However, in the case of Baker and Campbell, Justice Murphy ruled, apparently, that legal privilege did not extend to the legal transaction itself or to the details of financial transactions. My concerns about privacy appear to be mitigated by that judgment; although, I am far from clear on that.

The Attorney‐General has argued that the new reporting guidelines are not `onerous' on the solicitor. Further, the Attorney articulated that `the purpose of this anti‐organised crime legislation was to create an environment hostile to the successful commission of crime.' I cannot think of anyone who would seriously argue against that objective, with the possible exception of those intending to break the law! Certainly, the Law Council of Australia does not.

The issue of poorly defined terminology is not the sole concern of the Law Council, however. It has also expressed doubts about the wide ranging powers of authorised AUSTRAC personnel in accessing any document maintained at the premises of a solicitor. The Law Council asserts that:
This represents a significant infringement of the privacy of a much greater range of parties apart from the parties making reportable cash deposits.

However, it is important to note that AUSTRAC's power to access information is subject to the recognised solicitor-client privilege. Hopefully, that will ensure that the solicitor‐client relationship is not compromised by this legislation, or any other for that matter, that seeks to protect the financial sector from criminal abuse.

The Senate standing committee proposed that changes be made to the principal act to prevent the Australian Taxation Office—the ATO—from having a right to access financial transactions reporting data. Instead, the committee proposed that the ATO should be required to enter into a memorandum of understanding with the director of AUSTRAC if it wanted to access such data. In this way, the ATO would be placed on an equal footing with other law enforcement agencies. According to the Attorney‐General's department, the Civil Liberties Council is satisfied with the current provisions and, therefore, their views contributed to no further change.

The committee also made two recommendations that would see a civil liberties representative play a part in the oversight of the Financial Transaction Reporting Act. Recommendation 8 suggested that a civil liberties advocate be included in the ministerial advisory committee. Recommendation 9 proposed that the director of AUSTRAC should seek the advice of the Privacy Commissioner to determine whether a civil liberties representative should be appointed to an existing AUSTRAC advisory committee or whether an independent committee on privacy issues should be established. I am pleased to note that since the time of the release of the Senate committee report, a civil liberties representative has been appointed to both bodies.

The Senate committee also suggested that the FTR Act be amended to give the director of AUSTRAC the power to authorise the deletion of FTR information from the AUSTRAC database. The government has decided not to legislate on this matter because section 24 of the Archives Act 1983 already accommodates the deletion of such material.

All in all, this piece of legislation is unobjectionable. It appears to have sufficient checks and balances to ensure that those who act within the law can do so in the knowledge that their transactions will remain confidential. At the same time, it will enhance protection of Australia's financial sector from criminal intent.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to take the opportunity, despite the hour, of closing the debate on this bill. I would like to thank all members for their support of the bill and in particular those who spoke—the members for Banks (Mr Melham), Maribyrnong (Mr Sercombe) and Curtin (Mr Rocher).

SPEECH.PARA: As the member for Banks has observed, the bill essentially provides a number of non‐controversial amendments to a principal act that erects barriers against the infiltration and exploitation of the finance industry by criminal elements. Those amendments refine and improve the operations of the Financial Transaction Reports Act and are based on the Senate committee report Checking the Cash to which reference has been made.

Probably the most contentious—if that is the correct description of a non‐contentious piece of legislation—item in the bill relates to the requirement of solicitors to report significant cash transactions.

The member for Banks mentioned that particular measure with approval, and referred to reports of delinquent solicitors referred to in the Costigan report and NCA reports. It is regrettable that there are people within a profession whose position in society is designed upon the trust of the community who breach that trust by engaging in criminal activities. We have to live with that and part of the measure is designed to ensure that there is not an undue penalty on anybody who is observing the law.

The member for Maribyrnong expressed concerns in respect of two matters—solicitors reporting significant cash transactions and the provision of financial transaction reporting information to state and territory revenue authorities. He suggested that, in respect of each, there should be careful monitoring of the operation of those provisions. I recognise the point he is making—that this involves an intrusion into the privacy of the affairs of clients of solicitors and it involves a distribution of information that would otherwise be confined, in the second case.

However, as the member for Curtin has done in his speech, the government has carefully weighed and balanced the interests which compete in this context and has opted in the directions indicated. I have very carefully considered the question of involvement of solicitors in reporting the affairs of their clients and have discussed this with some representatives of the legal profession. I have to say that, to my recollection, the Law Council of Australia, at no stage, sought to discuss this matter with me but I did discuss it with the Law Institute of Victoria. I gave them the explanation and referred to the Costigan report and the NCA report. Those present seemed to be quite satisfied with the explanation, and I think the Law Council ought to be too.

The member for Maribyrnong referred to a number of recommendations from the Senate committee which, to his mind, had not been given effect to. I think, to some extent, his suggestions, particularly in respect of the civil liberties representative on the ministerial advisory committee, have been answered by the member for Curtin. Some other recommendations, I suggest, do not require legislative response and, since he did not identify them, I cannot really respond to them seriatim. I am advised that some of the recommendations were, in the course of consultation with industry, considered not necessary to be implemented at this time as there were alternative measures open.

In respect of the issues raised by the member for Curtin and, in particular, in the submission or representations made by the Law Council of Australia, I think the explanations that were offered to the member for Curtin by departmental officers, and one of my advisers, to a large extent, answered those queries. The reference to the definition of `transaction', which appears to be significant in the Law Council's submissions, appears also to be misconceived in that the term transaction is not relevant to significant cash transactions under the legislation but is relevant to suspect transactions which are not the subject of this legislation, at least in respect of solicitors.

The point made about the protection of the interests of third parties is an interesting one. However, to my way of thinking, it is difficult to identify who is, in fact, a third party. A client may come to the solicitor and present the solicitor with a large amount of cash, which is unusual in itself and is really the basis for the requirement of reporting. But that particular client may not be the owner of the money and may not be the intended recipient of the money. So what third party can we identify in the relationship between the client and the solicitor? I think, to some extent, that criticism is also misconceived.

The member for Curtin referred to AUSTRAC as deserving treatment as one of the law enforcement agencies. I think that in the administrative arrangements pertaining to my portfolio—and AUSTRAC is an independent agency—it is treated equally with the AFP, the NCA and my department in respect of most matters. It is separately represented on CLEB, the Commonwealth Law Enforcement Board, and is a distinct and separate participant in deliberations within the Office of Law Enforcement Coordination within my department.

Specific reference was made to the Australian Taxation Office. The Australian Taxation Office has voluntarily entered into a memorandum of understanding with AUSTRAC and has access to data on the same terms as other agencies. The civil liberties issue I think I have already covered. The civil liberties representation referred to by the member for Maribyrnong has been dealt with by the member for Curtin. I really think there is nothing further to be added to that.

In the light of the support for the legislation, I am pleased to commend the bill to the House. In concluding, I thank members who have contributed to the debate for their support and constructive comments.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.
